Make him 40 yo, give him a PhD, and you've got Bart Snapp. He's funny, approachable, and a little anti-establishment with his teaching style and his own online 'textbook'. Occasionally, he's a bit scatter-brained while solving example questions, but his lectures are generally well organized and easy to follow.

He is interesting and explains material well, but the class was extremely difficult. The homework doesn't prepare you for the final and is very basic. I thought the final made me fail, but a super generous curve (a little over 10% at the end) was given out luckily. Doesn't believe in quizzes and doesn't make you buy a textbook, which is nice.

Dr. Snapp always had very engaging lectures. He has a great sense of humor. He is good with answering questions, and wants to make sure students understand. The material isn't bad in the beginning, but the class moves very fast and gets challenging quickly. Exams are a huge majority of your grade.

Bart is very knowledgeable about the subject but the way the subject is taught was at a faster pace than expected. The homework though good practice only covers the concept in basic ways. The best way to excel would be to religiously attend his office hours and participate in them. Ask many questions about the intricacies behind the concepts.

Although Bart is very approachable and friendly his class is very tough. Bart weights the exams to 80% of your grade. So bad grades on exams a bad grade in the class. Also, I didn't find the recitation to be supplemental the lecture at all. However I will say the homework was very doable but wasn't a clear representation of the exams.
Great professor, obviously cares about teaching well and making sure the students have everything they need to learn.

Bart (who is very informal and funny) is a good teacher of Calc 3 and has a good grasp on the concepts - so he's able to explain them in a lot of different ways. Like most classes, to get a view of the content as a whole you have to put in a little effort but probably one of my favorite math classes (was my first at OSU).

Seriously, take math with this guy. He's one of the best in the math department. He posts his lectures online, but I was always motivated to go because he made me smile/laugh every lecture. He wrote the online textbook for the class (which was SUPER helpful because it was a similar style to his tests) so no need to buy one. Doesn't get much better.

He's an incredibly enthusiastic lecturer. He made attending class enjoyable. He's understanding, and he's willing to slow down for anybody who can't keep up. Receptive to questions, and doesn't consider any questions stupid. His teaching makes the class so much easier. I sometimes wish he was my dad too.

He's an excellent teacher, which makes up for the fact that the exams are usually unnecessarily difficult.  He re-graded my final exam and gave me some points back, which bumped me up to a C+ instead of a C.  His lectures are entertaining, and he does a great job of answering students' questions.  The math department sucks, but he's great.

Very entertaining lectures, as others have said. I also liked his lecture style of using sharpies on printer paper for slides. It seems like he puts a fair amount of work into preparing slides and then uploading them online, he really wants students to do well. He doesn't know what will show up on exams but he tries his best to guess.

He's very lively. I don't think it's possible to fall asleep in lecture. He tries to see what level your understanding is and goes off of that. Holds many office hours and if you can't make it he finds time for you. He can think of problems for you to solve on the spot and they really help. I would definitely take one of his classes again.

Bart is hands down the best math professor I have ever had. He's always there for students during office hours and after lectures. He will do everything in his power to ensure that his students succeed. The who don't do well in this course often don't put in the time to practice the material. This class was many things, but it wasn't boring.

Had a very basic math lecture with Bart and I assumed it would be the same boring thing week in and week out. Some how Bart managed to make things funs and exciting and made me look forward to class. He's funny and super smart.

He is funny and entertaining if you like calculus. He is very unclear sometimes and his notes are often unorganized and he doesn't give very many examples. You may think you know what you are doing but then when you go to take the test, there are a million curve balls thrown your way.

Calc was the biggest struggle with my freshman year, and I did not do well. However, this was due to many personal reason and the fact that I had a god awful TA. Bart himself is absolutely phenomenal, probably the best math professor at OSU. He's quirky, inspirational, and loves his job so much. He's always available to help and is just a great guy

Bart Snapp is the greatest Calc teacher you could have. I took his class and made it out with an A- without having any previous Calc experience. He'll teach you his way of doing Calc, which may be different from the book, but still very helpful. GO TO LECTURE! No need to buy the book, just get the MyMathLabs access; it'll come with an online book.

Bart Snapp is a phenomenal professor to have for Math 1151 - (Calc 1). His averages are ALWAYS higher than other professors. Take this professor for Calculus, or any other math course if you want to get a good grade. He goes over past exams in class.

Dr. Snapp is definitely one of the best professors you could ever have. Always ready to help if you need it. He makes dreams come true. Very good at teaching. Only class my first semester I actually felt like I was learning in. Gives amazing lectures and kept me engaged. Ask questions! He is always ready to answer

Bart was a great professor, and made the lectures interesting and personal to each student! Treated a class of 250 as a class of 25, and tried to get to know you. I have never seen a lecturer ask for problem requests at the beginning of class or one that  walks up and down the aisles.

He genuinely cares about the students, and he puts online videos of every lecture. Also he's pretty funny in a quirky way. He does all he can help, in spite of the math department heads who ruin everything...

Bart was great. He was very personable, understanding, and willing to answer questions. He was also quite humorous in class and answered emails promptly. During lectures, he made the material relatable and easier to understand.  He was scatter-brained occasionally in lecture, but I'd definitely choose his class again.
Bart is absolutely amazing. Best calculus professor I've ever had. He'll solve each and every one of your problems. He is extremely humorous and keeps everyone interested.

The best teacher I have ever had.  His class is hard but if you start the problems, he will direct you to the right answer.   Ask questions in class and go to office hours.  He is a wonderful teacher. Classes are hard, but its doable.

Bart was the best math teacher I ever had. He was so enthusiastic about teaching.He has an upbeat, fun personalty. He is very knowledgeable and has a way of teaching calculus so that it is very easy to understand. His class had the highest test scores on every midterm. His motto is to practice,practice,practice. Do that and you'll do fine!

Bart was a very fun teacher and very personable, especially since he let us call him by his first name. He made his own textbook for this class so that cut down on cost for the class. This class was a math class for architect majors so we got to learn math specific for our major, and even do fun projects like building 3D shapes and coloring!

Bart is a great teacher.  I had him for Math 108 and 109.  The class is very hard, just make sure you go to class and take the time to do the homeworks and study for the tests.  Bart makes the class very enjoyable though.  He also wrote me a letter of rec for grad school! :) If you have to take these courses, make sure you take them with him!
He was one of my favorite math teachers I have ever had. He will definitely challenge you, but he is VERY willing to help. Go to the lectures and you'll be just fine.
He was a great lecturer and was a very generous grader. Homework assignments were rough but the tests were very fair. He even rounded my grade at the end of the semester without me asking!

Dr. Kerler is a very kind professor who cares about his students and their success. Although a lot of content comes from the (free) textbook, he does a good job elaborating on the material to make lecture worthwhile. His grading scheme is very friendly, and if you put reasonable effort inside and outside of class, you should succeed.

10 HW during the semester, 5 exams. HW typically 5 questions from book. Exams were easy as long as you had a general understanding of the topics. Final was similar, just covered all course material and had more questions. Lectures a bit hard to follow while taking notes, so I didn't take any and just listened during lecture and read the book later.
I would run as far away as possible from this professor. I actually really enjoy math but he made it impossible for me to ever wanting to take math again.

Ok this professor is extremely smart. He makes up his own lecture material and can explain anything you'd like. He is concise and clear. He cares about his students and curves if necessary. Take his class if you can handle math or enjoy it.

Worst professor I have ever had in 3 years at Ohio State! Linear Algebra is easy, unless you take it with Kerler. Listen to everyone elses advice! If you have kerler, drop his class, dont enroll in it, avoid at all costs! Avoid him like the plague or you will be sorry!

Took an easy linear algebra class and made it impossible. Completely disorganized and was usually late or barely on time for class. My grades actually IMPROVED when I stopped going to class and just read the book. Complete joke of a professor and I expected more from OSU. You really dropped the quality ball on this professor OSU.

He's not a great teacher in this relatively easy subject. He's way over simple calculus and researches crazy stuff like "Topological Quantum Field Theories." I once heard that he wrote a book on time travel also. Anyway, since math 151 is review for most students it shouldn't be much trouble for non-dumb kids. I got an A easily. Just keep up!

I'm an A student in college. My only B+ was in his class. Words can't explain how awful this professor is. If you have him, you need to drop this class. If you are forced to take Math another quarter, do it. You will regret it if you do not drop the class.
Worst Prof i have ever had. didnt learn one thing in the class. drop his class!!!

alright.. he SUCKS!. I was always good at math in high school and then I got to his class and struggled so much.. I hardly went to lecturs though because it wasn't even worth it.  You can tell that he's really smart and knows what he is talking about but he has no clue how to transfer that information to others.
Very organized teacher and he really knew the subject matter, but I felt he was lacking in his ability to teach the students what we needed to know.

He is a terrible professor! He mutters constantly, and never really reaches the point that he is trying to make. The tests are impossible, cause they asked questions which were barely talked about in lecture. I would probably say he is the worst teacher I have ever had.
Not a bad prof, but not a good one either.
He is not a good teacher. Drop his class right now!
He can't explain things worth a damn. thank god i took calc in high school.
Very clear, very simple, straight German-style instruction. Fellow students mostly idiots,  very stupid. Ohio-State -- what can you expect? I liked very much his humorless jokes.

People tell you to go to lectures-for Kerler there is no need. he mumbles and never gets his point across. If there is a problem that is too difficult for him he will just pass it up. BE SURE TO GO TO RECITATION!  Park is probably youre best bet for a good TA. If you have kerler as a prof, i recommend attending a different lecture; he is useless

ABSOLUTELY AWFUL. I got an B+ in 15O, i'm pretty good at math but I got an E in his class, worst grade of my life.  His lectures cover maybe 10% of the exam problems, but the problems he does cover are 10x harder on the exam.  The entire class averaged a 55.1% total.I retook the class with another professor and got another B+. GET OUT OF HIS CLASS!
i can't even begin to explain how much he can't teach.he cracks jokes every once in a while, but theyre not funny. Every other calc class seeme dto have an advantage over ours in the exams.
His accent is easy enough to get over, but you will still have no idea what he's talking about.
Ugghh.  This guy makes Calculus 10x harder than it should be.  I got an E in his class.  If I take calc again, it's not going to be with Kerler.

ABSOLUTELY POSITIVELY HORRIBLE!  i can't even begin to explain how much i hated going to his class.  i didnt learn one thing.  never passed an exam and didnt pass the class.  he basically screwed my GPA.  for god's sake get another professor for this class.
If you have kerler i recommend sitting in on another professors lectures. All 151 exams are basically the same, Curve is about 10% so not bad on that respect.

class wasn't as bad as everyone wanted to think it was.  I got a 30/80 on a midterm and still got an A.  The final wasn't bad either i got a 190/200, the class is not that bad and you need to take it for most majors.
Terrible, search for another Prof
SUCKS
He is an idiot.  He is a jerk.  And you cant reason with him.  He is always wrong. If you have him, go to a different lecture..BEST thing you can do.  It will save your grade.
Bad teacher, bad TA, bad class... need I say more?

Terrible teacher. Impossible to understand. He spent the entire 48 min. working on one problem when he'd ultimately realized even he couldn't do it. I failed every midterm and got a 96/200 on the final and still got a C with the curve though.

Kerler was the absolute worst teacher I have ever had.  He's a smart-ass prick who gives out test that are harder than any problem you see in the homework or recitation classes.  Our class average was 50.1 he does an awful job in explainations of problems, no curve, and makes constant mistakes.

He is a very bad teacher. My grade improved when I stopped going to lecture and just learned the stuff on my own. The tests have nothing to do with homework problems. Basically, if you're really smart you'll do well...I you're not... good luck.
His voice would be loud and soft and he would make mistakes but not tell you where to correct them. He was just very hard and he made me not want to go to class.
Tests are nothing like homework problems or quizes. Has a good sense of humor though.

I understand why people think he's a bad professor but I think he's kind of cute and I guess it was easy for me because I had taken calculus in high school, but for those that didn't then I guess it would have sucked.  He wasn't the worst though.
He needs to test over what he teaches, basically there's a problem with the entire structure of the math department, and things need to be changed.
strong german accent but still pretty easy to understand. i completely understand what he does i lecture, but the tests are always a lot harder. he really tries, and will help you if needed.

Calc. was at least understandable in H.S.-but he made it seem like like rocket science, taught in LATIN!  He wore the same red shirt every day, called calculators "computers" and called himself "vertically dyslexic". I ended up with a C+ in the class, but actually failed it without a curve......
No Comments

if you didn't already take calculus before in high school, you're pretty much screwed unless youre really good at teaching yourself stuff youve never heard of in your life. mumbles and has a heavy accent. lecture and practice problems never even slightly resemble exams. good luck:)

Wow, this guy is horrible! He has absolutely no idea that the students gain nothing from attending his lectures. Thank god Matt was my TA. in 10 minutes i learned from Matt what it would take Kerler 2 lectures to explain badly.

this guy sucks. he doesnt know how to teach.. he shows us the hardest possible problem in class and expects us to understand his mumbling****. his midterms are **** cuase he doesnt even look at them til the day of the exam because they are departmental exams.
No Comments

Watching him teach would be comical, if it weren't my grade on the line. He just mumbles incoherently, and expects us to know exactly what he is talking about. Very disorganized; he failed to show up for a test. His personal hygene is lacking.

Not a good professor. Just mumbles on like Bill Murray from Caddyshack. Doesnt really explain things, just does them and expects you to understand. Not very helpful, just refered me TAs. Put me to sleep.
cant understand, mumbles for a while then shouts in lectures, examples are not well explained, Quinlan is a great TA though
He is terrible.  The review exams online are nothing compared to his.  He makes everything complicated and hard.  He is just aweful.
If you get him, my only words of advice are to drop the class ASAP.  He is pathetic.  If you get Avi Silterra as a TA, do yourself a favor and shoot yourself.  You will thank me later.
i dont understand how this dude made professor, he suxs hard core.Does not clean his cloths nor apparently himself.i had to drop this class. Definitily avoid avi silterra, he is kerler times ten.
Makes no sense, mumblesand is not clear. Avoid at all costs

This guy is more of a neanderthal than an educated professor, mumbles and smells repugnant. Biggest head of any professor I've ever seen. If you can decipher his grunts then you'll be fine, if not (which is far more likely) then you are officially screwed
If Quinlan is your TA, you should be fine, if not... RUN!
I cannot understand this guy AT ALL...the only thing that is worse than his lecture is the horrible teaching of Avi Silterra as a TA, avoid this combination like the plague
No Comments
No Comments
Mumbling and lateness issues. Has trouble bathing regularly. Does not change clothes often.

He teaches like a tornado!  If you can understand a mumbling german accent and garbled math, then you might be okay in his class.  On the other hand, if you're like me and require an explanation of the concepts being taught, then DON'T TAKE HIS CLASS!!!!!

If you have him as a professor, you will be shafted. One, you can;t understand him and two, he isn;t prepared. Also, don;t if possible, get him as a prof and Avi Silterra as a TA, because you are on your own!

This course is very difficult but Jenny is very understanding and helpful when it comes to help with assignments. The grading scale for this class is a bit odd but it allows for you to not do amazing on tests but still do relatively okay. I enjoyed having her as a professor, it's clear that she wants her students to do well.

The grading scheme made little sense and was way out of left field. She does allow for corrections, but how the scale is set up, you could get A's on almost all of the assignments, but if you get even one C your highest possible grade is a C+. Additionally she has the students, mostly, teach themselves. Also tries to pass being mean as funny

Jenny is absolutely amazing at teaching a class that is quite hard. Elem math for teachers is not for the weak but it's a course that helps build your persistence to do well. Jenny gives you lots of tries so a good work ethic and attitude will likely result in a good grade. Already scheduling for Jenny's class next semester- she's that wonderful!

Jenny is a great professor and very caring towards her students. I had her for 2168. You must go to class, it is very participation heavy on the white boards! Interesting material and she is passionate about teaching math.

Jenny is absolutely amazing! The grading is really wacky but she understands that it is a hard course and WANTS you to succeed. As with any class, it's important that you speak up if you need help because she is so understanding and happy to help. Definitely try to take math 1125 with Jenny and don't give up!!

Jenny is by far the best professor I've ever had. 1125 is an extremely challenging class, but not impossible. Jenny really cares that we do well and understands that this class is challenging. Office hours are a lifesaver because of the weird grading system and all the homework. Find study buddies to ask questions and prepare for timed assessments.

The grading scale for this course is very different, but Jenny and the TAs want you to succeed. The semester will start off rough and shaky, but Jenny makes an effort to make sure you feel comfortable and confident in the classroom.

Jenny is a fantastic teacher! Make sure you take MATH 1125 with her! This class is challenging, but as long as you try, you will do well! I would really utilize all the office hours. It makes class and understanding the material so much easier!

Professor Sheldon does a really good job when one-on-one. She is super helpful in a difficult class with a difficult grading system. Sometimes the lectures aren't great, but I would recommend going to her office hours and asking for help since she is good one-on-one.

TAKE JENNY FOR 1125! This is definitely the most challenging class I've taken at OSU, but with Jenny's instruction, it was made easier. Jenny truly wants her students to succeed. My advice (will make more sense once you take the class): get your reassessments done early, use the textbook for help on your explanations, and go to office hours.

Jenny is honestly such a great professor but is judged by the hard tests and complicated grading of the class!! She was super helpful and understanding and made the class fun! However, the grading system is certainly unique and can be frustrating to figure out how to succeed. Overall shes a great teacher teaching a hard class.
one of the hardest classes you will ever take. no partial credit given it's all or nothing. professor is somewhat helpful but NEVER lenient with points. good luck.

This was by far the most difficult class I have taken at OSU. The grading system is unique- you have to fully understand content, or not at all. Yet, Jenny is an incredibly understanding, kind, and funny professor. She is always willing to help and work with you. If you demonstrate effort, you will have the opportunity to succeed!

First teacher I've had in college that I felt like really cared about my well-being. We often split up into breakout rooms, which I think was actually helpful for my learning the material. Very different from other OSU math courses, at times it felt more like classes I'd have taken in high school, but in a good way.

Jenny is one of the most helpful, dedicated professors I've ever had. She spent countless hours in n out of class helping students. I had many 1 on 1 meetings with her bc I needed the extra help, and w/o I would have probably failed the class. I've had all A's except one B, and I could barely pass this class. Class info will be helpful in future.

Jenny is a great person and gives you lots of opportunities to gets points but the structure of this class is horrendous. The worst class I have ever taken. It truly kept me up at night. The entire class is a guessing game. Hours spent on 1 homework for 1 word feed back and no points. You teach yourself everything or rely on classmates help.

The whole structure of this class made no sense. Every lecture was spent in breakout rooms where more than half the class time was wasted. It would take us 5 minutes to do the problem but we would reconvene with 5 minutes remaining to go over each groups answer. There was literally zero instruction and the textbook is how i made it. take at cstate

One of the hardest courses I've ever taken, but Jenny provides so many options to get your grade up with Reassessments, and she will meet with you outside of office hours if needed to help you with concepts (DFUs) definitely would take her classes again if I could because she is passionate about what she does.

Jenny should definitely be reported for the way her class is set up. There are no letter grades in this class, only outcomes. She grades way too harshly. She also never teaches and has us rely on our peers to teach each other. So basically some of our tuition is going to a professor who is trying to sabotage our grades

Jenny grades with a system based on Outcomes you have to get through hw and exams but its impossible to do well in this system. The criteria to hit an outcome is very wordy so you think you know what youre doing but its so wordy its unclear and she almost never gives you the outcome. She doesnt grade all of the hw problems you do either.

I'm sure this class was great before outcomes, yet it has made this class almost impossible. Grades are based on how many outcomes you master, but you have to hit every single point of each outcome perfectly to receive a DFU. The only way to get DFU is on hw or exam but they dont even grade all of your work. Class is all group work and no teaching.

By far the hardest class I've taken at OSU. This class is literally a game. During class, we had to learn from our peers and she did nothing but grade. This whole class is just set up to make you fail. Your grade is based off how many outcomes you can "master."

By far the best professor Ive had at OSU! The class is inanely difficult but you will walk away having learned so much. If youre on the fence of taking 1172 or 2162 take the latter. She focuses class around discussion ideas instead of just computations. Tests are hard but homework and quizzes are weighted a good amount too so it distributes.

She is awesome! I really admire her stamina on teaching a whole classes of students with so many questions with solving their questions as well as bring new contents for a whole class. The pace is fast, but her discussion is really a good place to think over the classes. 80% points of all quizzes will be marked as all points so it's totally fine.
Jenny is a very good teacher. If you put in the effort, you can be successful in her class. The material does move quickly but if you stay on top of things and work hard, you will do well.

Jenny is a good teacher, but this class is the most difficult I have ever taken. Very little partial credit given on tests, which are pretty hard to begin with. Jenny does her best to get us through this class, and her lectures are pretty helpful. If you have the option, DO NOT take 2162, but if you do and have Jenny, you could do much worse.

Jenny is a great professor! The class is more difficult than expected, but if you work hard to understand things you'll do fine. There's weekly quizzes, weekly homework, and 3 exams. It's a decent amount of work but really not too bad. Jenny is great at explaining things and genuinely wants to help you, I really enjoyed her as a professor!!

Despite her being an excellent teacher, I do not recommend anyone to take Math2162. I didnt miss a single lecture, got almost full credit in all the homework but still couldnt get a good score on this course. Dont take 2162 Unless you are a math wizard. It is not fair to say Jenny is a bad teacher, its either this course is too hard or Im dumb

Jenny was a wonderful professor for Math 1125. She gave us a lot of opportunities to talk about our ideas in class and that helped me work through what I was struggling with. You do get a grade for attendance and participation that can help increase your score at the end of the class, so show up and speak up!

While Jenny cares about the students in her class, she does not communicate the material well at all. Recitation is where I actually learned the concepts and how to do problems. I would not recommend 2162 to anyone taking any other honors class because the workload is so much and the tests are difficult due to how much information they cover.

I really enjoyed having Dr. Jenny as my professor for 2162. It's a super hard class but she really cares about her students and having them understand calculus. She gets to know everyone's name and is very helpful with questions. She can be a little quirky at times and is really into class participation but still a solid professor.

Pros: -Extremely helpful during office hours -Learned everyone's name (100/class) and connected with everyone -Challenged us  Cons: -Occasionally came across as clueless -Lectures were very similar to the book (pro maybe?)  Jenny's class was ridiculously hard. That's not really her fault, considering you are flying through calc 2 AND 3.

I felt like she didn't actually teach us in class. Lectures felt like recitation and recitation felt like a study hall. I felt that you had to read the textbook outside of class to actually understand how her 'lectures' (lecture  giving the class a problem to work on and kind of guiding us when we got stuck) related to what we should've read.

Dr. Sheldon values her relationship with the students, as she called students by name in two classes of 100+ people. She was good during office hours and tests were fairly created and graded. Yes, the class was hard, but "Honors" isn't supposed to be easy. She was great during office hours. The students who put effort into the class did well

2162 is a horrible class and I do not recommend it at all. It is not required for FEH, and it covers part of calc 2 and all of calc 3 in only one semester, which is way too much material. The class this year was not even curved. We didn't get enough examples in class, and a lot of points would be taken off on tests for small errors.
A lot of material over a short amount of time. Lectures are a lot of material with few examples. Easier to take calc 2 and 3 separately

Jenny is a different professor to say the least. The amount of material covered in class is too much to have a comprehensive final, and the work you spend only one day on in class is too hard to grasp in such a short amount of day. The semester is spent rushing through two textbooks and the information doesn't stick because of the difficulty level.

Odd professor; she makes jokes, but they're often in leu of student behavior and their answers to her questions. She once referred to below average academic performing students as "bottom of the barrel". Her lectures are helpful and she does a nice job teaching the material, I would just prefer a professor with a more professional demeanor.
Class time work had nothing to do with the midterm or final exams. Graded extremely hard and was disrespectful to students about how they did.

Class was semi-enjoyable and not super difficult, but final grades are completely unreasonable. There are barely any homework assignments in the class, so most of your grade is based on the midterm and take-home final. The take-home final has no clear rubric, and is not similar to what we did in class at all.

The class time work was very simple and easy, but the midterm did not have much to do with what we learned at all and he graded extremely tough. The final was a take home final and he said it would be graded before the end of the semester, but it was not  and really hurt some people's grades who depended on this final to bring their grade up.
The actual class time work was very easy and simp

He assigned homework which he would never grade or give us feedback on. We didn't have a single exam. On the last class, he asked us what the final should be. In the end, he didn't grade anything that we turned in. I received an A because I participated in class. But, others received a B with no explanation as to why they earned that grade.

Professor Findell works hard to make his lectures interesting. The workload is reasonable. I'd definitely take a course with him again. The biggest issues with his classes are that the midterm and finals come out of nowhere and often aren't graded before the semester is over.
You'll love him if you have a sense of dry humor. Practice exams are very useful. The homework was the hardest part of this class.

I wanted an easy A, but this is more like an easy C if you don't study for the midterms. But if you do, you'll pass with a good grade. Pro tip: the practice exams almost exactly match them.

He's a passionate guy that gives you the tools to pass if you just do the work. I would take him again.
Condescending and uncaring for students. disrespectful

I'm not a math person and his class was very confusing to follow especially after the first midterm. The textbook is confusing to follow and understand, but his lectures are decent if you understand the course materials. He does "talk to your neighbors" too often. If he used that time to go through examples that would have been very helpful.

took way too long to put grades in which was super frustrating. had no grades in for half the semester even though there was weekly homework. also bad at responding to emails. other than that, the class really wasnt bad if you did the work and paid attention. he was decent

This class is the hardest one I have ever taken. Brad is a good guy and he is passionate about math, but as a prof he is really confusing, gets off topic, and is a hard grader. You have to work extremely hard to get a relatively good grade, but it really isnt worth all the stress. Brad means well, but he isnt a great prof. Good luck with him.

(BTW, I took the MATLAB section/text). His lectures are easy to follow and cover the basics, but if you don't read the textbook in addition you will struggle with the homework/exams. A nice and caring person, and helpful in office hours. His exams covered more of the basics/fundamentals of what is in the textbook, so weren't very difficult.
slow. boring. he likes to say "talk to your neighbor" which is annoying

He goes slow in lecture like really slow, and he emphasizes the basics; the foundation so that you can really understand if you learn a bit slowly However, because of this he doesnt have time to go through the hard & more useful topics & examples that are covered in the homework & the exams. Leading you to figure it out by yourself. take @ cstate!

Brad is my favorite professor I've had at Ohio State. I have had in for two semesters. He barely gives us homework and class is discussion based. The first semester he provided pizza every other class. I enjoy math more when I am in his class.

This class will be your favorite class if you're big into math, if you don't enjoy math, buckle up. Brad is a good teacher and very flexible to meet students needs. If you talk to him about having trouble with deadlines he will for sure help you out. The homework is pretty tough though, you won't do well without going to office hours weekly.

Brad really requires his students to think for themselves. The math textbook is used every lecture and recitation because the activities we do in class are included in the book. Luckily the book is cheap. The homework is difficult so it's important to attend office hours and work on the homework early. Do NOT procrastinate!

Brad isn't as bad as everyone makes him out to be. Sure he isn't the best teacher, but if you attend class and office hours you will do fine in the class. For all those people that said he is a hard grader, they are wrong because Brad doesn't even grade the homework the TA does; if anything this class is dependent on the TA you get, not Brad.

I did not enjoy this class. It was only passible if you went to office hours to work on the homework. I did not like Brad's teaching style at all. We spent the entire class figuring out how to solve problems by ourselves and then were told how it relates to what we are learning in the last 5 minutes if we were even told.

I spent hours and hours completing homework, attending all of the office hours provided and still received a bad grade. Brad makes students feel bad about their ability to be a teacher. This was by far the worst class I have taken thus far. The way this class is set up is rigged. It is also very hard to get your grade to improve.

Absolutely terrible. I was told this class was easier for people who do not like math, that was a lie. The teacher was horrendous. On multiple occasions he would put questions on exams we were never taught how to do. He will give you homework weekly, but don't expect to see the grade you got on it until after the semester is over.
Class sizes are small and you learn a lot so you need to be there every day. Also at office hours every time or you really wont pass.

Pretty bad professor. He used to send emails basically incentivizing people to go to his lectures saying that those who went got ten percent higher grades. Most people still did not go with only thirty out of 130 students going. Go to recitation and study on your own. His teaching style is not useful so I would skip his lectures.

Spent all of my semester doing homework and studying for this class. Had to attend multiple office hours a week to get even a B on the homework assignments and exams. Brad is intelligent and cares a lot about his students, the class is simply just made much harder than needed.

Brad can be a decent professor at times, but I would still have to say he is one of the worst math professors I have had. Be prepared to spend at least 10 hours a week on this class alone. The homework is graded extremely hard and you basically HAVE to go to office hours if you want any chance of doing well. This class takes a toll on you for sure.

He is not a bad professor, I personally just didn't learn well from his teaching style. When discussing math problems and ideas, he would never work out problems during lecture. The only practice I had was during recitation and on my own / homework. Recitation for me was mandatory in order to understand the material.

Brad was one of the better math professors that I have had at OSU. He cares about his students and is willing to work you through any questions that you have. The homework and exams would have been very difficult without attending his office hours so make sure you find time to go. If you  work hard you will get a lot out of Brad as your professor.

You have to work hard for this class. Go to office hours or you will not do well. Do the sample problems he gives you, some will appear on the exams. Stay organized or you will regret it. He can be very confusing at times and can talk down to you, but he does care about each of his students and wants the best for us.

At first impression, Dr. Findell seems boring and stiff. But once he gets to know the class, he's really nice and loosens up a lot, and is always willing to help you. Go to his tutor room hours because he was extremely helpful on homeworks and studying for exams. Class material is somewhat difficult but not terrible. Overall a really nice guy.

Class was very difficult as it mostly deals with proofs, which I personally struggle with. Koenig has a very dry sense of humor but it's obvious he cares about his students understanding what he's teaching and encourages questions. He talks quietly so sit toward the front of the class. Wouldn't take the class again but would take it with him again.

Professor Koenig is extremely knowledgeable about mathematics, and relies on his own methodology of teaching the class rather than following the textbook. However, he sometimes fails to convey information (which is understandable due to the abstract nature of the class), requiring rigorous reading of the textbook.
Dr. Koenig has a dry, but awesome sense of humor. He is incredibly fair, especially compared to other 3345 instructors. I would definitely recommend him for 3345.

Prof. Koenig is an occasionally funny guy with a genuine passion for teaching math. He knows his notes front to back and is great at explaining things but sometimes assumes you know things that you probably don't. Show up to class, take good notes, and study at least a few days before exams and you will pass. Make sure to actually try on the HW.

Dr. Koenig is an excellent professor. He is very clear, his exams are very fair, and his homework is manageable. The course material can be difficult at times, but if you show up and participate it's not bad.

Hes pretty knowledgeable as a professor but the class is difficult. Knows hes taking about. He mumbled through lecture so kinda hard to understand. His final nearly killed everyone though and the topics at the end were brutal. Be ready to be good at proofs.

Pretty cool guy. The only real complaint I have against him is that he talks soft and kinda mumbles and its kinda hard to get what he is trying to say. But he is very helpful and its pretty easy to follow his lecture notes. Also helpful when you ask questions.
Great prof overall! The exams were fair, and there was a manageable amount of homework. My only complaint is he goes over time in lectures by 5 to 10 minutes each lecture.
He explains topics very well and gives great walkthroughs of new and old topics and methods. Although I do not enjoy Calculus, he definitely has improved my views on it.

His lectures are easy to understand, he cracks math jokes which tends to be the normal for most good math teachers at OSU, and although the class itself can get hard, it wont if you ask questions during recitation and send emails. During fall semester he only graded homework and exams and the participation grade recitations was decided by the TA.
Awesome professor! Id recommend going to his office hours if you missed the lectures.

I really wasn't looking forward to this class at all but Dr. Koenig made it way more enjoyable than I thought it was going to be. His sense of humor is great too. Exams weren't too bad and homeworks were reasonable.

Dr. Koenig is a nice professor who cares a lot about making the class interesting and understandable. Very witty guy. He does not make tests as hard as the homework is (except for the bonus question) and keeps grading criteria and length of tests fair. He's amazing and you'll come out with a decent grade and a good understanding of math.
Great lecturer. He loves to joke around. You'll get an A as long as you do your homework.
Best professor I've had at OSU. Hilarious and cool guy, and clearly passionate about math.

Good professor overall. He speaks rather softly so you may need to sit up front. Sometimes he spent a bit more time on proofs than what I would've liked. Roughly 75% of the grade was exams, but they were quite fair exams in my opinion. Awkward dude but is pretty funny at times. No other faults that I can think of. Would take again.

Excellent professor.  He makes sure to explain things in multiple ways and tie everything together for maximum clarity.  He is enjoyable to listen to, and he often cracks jokes about how boring and redundant the material can be.  Highly recommend taking him, he is incredibly fair.

Koenig is the man! Going to his lectures and doing the homework he assigns ensures you will get a good grade, as long as you're taking the time to actually understand the subject material. He is obviously very intelligent and passionate about the subject, along with having a pretty corny and quirky sense of humor. Would definitely take again.

It sounds like he is a pretty good professor for other classes, but do NOT take him for Math 2174! Averages were way lower than other section and he taught everything very abstractly with proofs and theory. Managed to do okay on the first couple of tests but the final (worth 40%) was BRUTAL!!

Math 2153: 3 exams and a Final. No homework ect. to buffer grade. However, GREAT professor. Explains things in multiple ways for all types learners. Skips a lot of material from textbook. Exams are not necessarily easy, but very straight forward/not tricky. If you mess up an exam you kinda screwed. Tip: review chapter before attending its lecture.

Nothing out of the ordinary.  He wasn't a super great professor, but he wasn't a bad one either.  At times it seems as if he is moving a little fast and other times it's the right speed.  If you pay attention and do the homework, you'll be fine.
Great professor, definitely recommend, very fair.  Class is structured to help you get a good grade.  If you show up, ask for help, and participate he will help you grade wise.

He's very shy and awkward. He's a pretty good lecturer and helpful one on one. However his tests are unfair. Half the test is multiple choice with no partial credit. So while the other 2177 classes are getting As your getting low Bs.

Probably the best thing about Prof. Koenig is that he is very down to earth and not caught up in particulars. He likes to joke around in class and show what he thinks are the more "fun" proofs of calculus. He is also very very good at the math, so he can always fall back on his thorough understanding of the topic to help you more

I love this guy. He's got a corny sense of humor that helps makes lectures enjoyable, and he really knows and portrays the subject matter well. He can digress from the material in class, but he always covers each subject thoroughly and is very straightforward about what you need to know. Try to get him if you have the chance, you won't regret it.

Koenig talks quietly in lecture so sit in front.  Exams are very straight forward.  Homeworks every week are very helpful (utilize MSLC or office hours).  Textbook is good.  Lectures are not super helpful.  He gives problems without really explaining the concept.  I learned more in recitation and at the MSLC.
Great Prof. Talks quietly so sit in the front. Very fair.
He is very fair in his class. If you come to class and put in the time with the homework, it is an easy class. If you don't the class can be difficult. His exams are more than fair.

The class itself is extremely difficult.  Professor Koenig made the material slightly interesting, but over all the class was boring.  His midterms were more than fair, if not slightly easy.  Final was harder than anticipated, but he made it open note.

Very intelligent math teacher/lecturer. There aren't any troubling faults in his methods. He has the occasional awkward one-liner (which helps lightens the mood during an intense lecture on triple integrals) and he is very clear and concise with what he is teaching.

Dr. Koenig was very helpful and a very clear and concise instructor. I have taken several math classes at OSU, and so far he is definitely the best one I have ever had. The only terrible thing about the class is the final. It is multiple choice (with choices A through F) and you get no points for partial credit.
He's pretty easy if you show up to class. Doing the homework is 25% and he usually gives a bonus on every test and quiz. Plus he loves math and he definitely shows it.

Overall, Prof. Koenig is an excellent teacher. His tests are very fair and he is very helpful in office hours. His only drawback is his soft voice (but you can hear him fine sitting in the first few rows). I was disappointed to learn that he will not be teaching 263 this quarter.
Very passionate professor, and interesting/entertaining lecturer. Course was very hard though.
Best of the possible teachers. All the other classes had midterm averages in the 20s. Exams are fair and straight forward. Take him if you can!

If you get this guy you got a gym. Be ready for a blast of mathmatical computation with a fun adventure of humor. He made class fun and was very helpful to students. If you want know your stuff take him. Quizzes and Test are easy if you memorize notes and do homework. Final is rough but is do able. The best math teacher I've had thus far.
Amazing teacher!! His jokes are sometimes kinda corny, but it keeps series and parametric curves worth staying awake for.

Amazing professor. Lectures were often confusing (and cold) and were sometimes hard to apply to the homework. However, the midterms were very straightforward and fair. The final also wasn't bad. Overall, he was a good professor. Just don't get freaked out if you don't understand the lecture - you'll still be able to figure out the homework.

Koenig is an exemplary math professor. He has a knack for explaining things in a manner that is not overly complex and confusing, but also not so simple as to prevent a complete understanding. He was, ultimately, one of the best professors I have had at OSU, without a doubt.

His lectures move fast but he writes everything on the board so it is easy to follow. Even if you don't really follow the lecture, when you get to the homework you realize that you actually did learn something.

Fun professor, keeps class pretty interesting, and he writes everything he says on the board in a way thats easy to keep up with but not so slow you get bored.  Tests are straight-forward and if you've done the homework or watched his in-class examples you won't have a problem.  Strongly recommended.
Nice guy, geeky but somewhat humerous jokes...makes class worth going to, very straightforward with material presented and exams...definitely would take his class again

He was difficult to get used to at first, and his assignments are relatively challenging.  HOWEVER, if you go to his office hours, he is extremely helpful, and he even hosted office hours to help with the take-home portions of his exam.  He's a funny and geeky guy, but his class was pretty enjoyable.  I'd take another class of his any day.

Koenig is a good teacher and a really nice person. His homework assignments are not time consuming, but they reinforce the material and are nicely weighted and if you do them the midterms and final aren't bad. He honestly cares about his students and wants you to do well - he curves generously and gives take-home portions of the tests. Great class.

VERY GOOD PROFESSOR! Class was fairly graded and the exams and quizzes are almost identical to the examples given in class, bonus questions on quizzes and exams.  Homework is very heavily weighted but do it and the exam grades will come easy.  The only qualm I have is that our final was multiple choice with six answer choices a piece.

Excellent professor!  His math jokes spice up lecture.  Homework assignments are reasonable, and tests are very similar.  Generally a fairly easy class, except kinda fast paced and most of the proofs are pretty challenging.  Take it with Koenig, you won't regret it!
funny,helpful,somewhat looks like 'peter parker' geek type

It is refreshing to be taught by someone who speaks clearly and teaches well. Plus, his midterms aren't made to screw you over. AND he curves the final grade really nicely. He's a nice guy. I'd take him for the rest of my math classes, if I could.
Difficult course, but very clear and helpful. Spoke clearly and was a good lecturer. Pretty tough final though, as well as heavily weighted homeworks and quizzes.
Great professor, teaches well, and really cares about how his students do in the class. Midterms are straightforward and based on the homework.
Very intresting lectures. Humorous. Very cool guy and helpful! Check out his shoes if you have him! :)
Helpful guy, is concerned about the students. Funny in lecture, quizzes and homework are average. Midterms were fair, but watch out for the fastball final..I'd take him again.

He was my best math teacher I've ever had.  He has the most amazing choice of shoes and makes funny comments in class.  Although i think he's a straight up gangsta when it comes to the mathematics but his final is no joke.  Nonetheless, it was a pleasure to be in his presence during class.I love him
The course was challenging. He sometimes has a hard time amplifying his voice enough. He teaches a good class and is an average teacher.
Nice guy, wants students to do well and is helpful. Midterms are fair and quizzes and homeworks aren't bad.
pretty straight forward quizzes, midterms, final.  Pretty much lets you know what kind of problems to expect.  I'd take this guy again.

As several other students have noted, it helps to possess a vocabulary that would make the ETS blush (or at least one that can get you a 700+ on the SAT Verbal).  Nevertheless, very knowledgeable but often finishes examples all the way through even though the students should already know how to do s

Seems to be one of the best for 254 that I've heard of but the vocabulary used in leacture can remind me of an English class. Tries to make things pretty straight forward about what will be on exams and seems to care about you doing well.

He's a good professor.  However, he uses vocabulary in lecture that will confuse you unless you already have a PhD in Math.  But his exams aren't bad and they don't stray too far from his HW.  Plus he really wants his students to do well.

Hilarious and geeky guy. Lectures are very confusing, but the homework helps you learn the material and pass the exams. My only complaint was the final that was weighted 50% of the class grade (he dropped the last midterm and its 30% average)

He is a very nice guy, and when you go to his office hours, he helps you out a lot. His examples sometimes help on the homework, but not for a whole lot of problems.  He is a really nice guy, but it is true, he does mumble when he gives lectures sometimes, but If u pay attention, you should be fine

Its sometimes difficult to follow what he talks about during lecture, but he does lots of examples.  Just do all the HW because the questions he asks on exams are very similar.  The exams were easy and an A in the class isn't that hard.
This professor is horrible. He speaks way too softly, doesn't explain anything, and writes extremely small on the board so nothing can be read. All in all, a terrible teacher.

Lectures suck but for tests he sends out an email with the topics that are going to be on it and generally sticks to what he says so if u study tests aren't that bad. But final is most of the grade which is annoying and he is not helpful in emails or anything

This is the worst professor I have taken in my entire college career. His lessons follow no structure, he is unorganized, and there is zero chance anyone can follow what he writes on the board. He is EXTREMELY bad at arithmetic, which resulted in errors in nearly every calculation he did. As someone who pays for college themselves, WASTE OF MONEY.

I know many students didn't love Prof. Derdzinski, but if you attend lectures (even if you don't) and stay up to date with the syllabus and the topics covered per week- you will be just fine. I really recommend watching tons of YouTube videos for many chapters as he doesn't necessarily go over things again and again, but I enjoyed his class a lot.

Your entire grade basically comes down to how you do on the exams, which often require either remembering or having previously learned some trick to simplify the problem. Each problem missed results in a sizable penalty to final grade. Exam averages were well below passing, and no curve was applied to exams or final grades.

I would not recommend Professor Derdzinski. I looked at these reviews prior to taking his class and decided to take a chance on him, but I really should not have. I have never once dropped a professor, but I really wish I did in this case. His exam averages are well below passing grades (yes, well below a C-). Please do not take this class.

It says I got a C-, but I should have gotten a B, because he completely forgot to put in my midterm 1 score. When I asked him to input the score, he told me that he did not have the test records. However, even though I took the test, he refused to give me anything but a 0 on that test, causing my entire grade to drop from a theoretical 81 to a 66.

So much to say with so little room.
He is living proof that SEIs do nothing. The horrible ratings here are completely true. DROP HIM IF YOU HAVE HIM. I am retaking this class and there are at least 4 (out of about 24) students retaking this class in my section because of him. He does not follow the textbook and his exams do not follow the lecture

If you have him as your instructor, DROP THAT CLASS! He doesn't post notes online. He doesn't do a good job explaining in class. Reading the provided book is more reliable than his teaching. He got mad at me when I asked for help at office hours. Many students failed his exams. Many even tried to get the math department to do something about this.

Avoid this guy at all costs, drop the class for the semester, get a different professor, literally anything but this section. Nonsensical math vomit lectures brushing off advanced topics as "arbitrary" and ridiculous grader. Uninterested in answering questions or helping students. Class average of 62 right now. Keep the D off your transcript.

He is impossible to understand during class and does not take questions. He is rude and uncaring during office hours. I read the entire book and still got a 50 on the exam. (Higher than the class average of 40, though.) He grades extremely harshly, one small mistake and you get a fourth of the credit on the question, each exam is only 4 questions.

Yeah, I read these reviews and tried giving him a shot to see for myself. I mean, he can't be that bad, especially 'cause he has some good reviews, right? Yeah, no. He is truly that bad lol. I delayed my math curriculum just to drop his class. Rather that than a D in a class that doesn't give curves or use any technology.

This guy sucks. He never actually teaches, he just tells. I can tell that he's so smart and knows what he's talking about but he expects you to be on the same level as him. He starts by teaching chapter 5 and expects you to know everything else. He hated the entire class for asking questions and got mad when we were confused about his content.

Classes are punctual and completely non-interactive. Professor will arrive the minute class starts, write as many proofs as they can on the board without turning to face the class or ask if anyone has questions until the last five minutes, but only to see the exact second they can leave. Exam means were 50%'s with no curve. Avoid them at all costs.
One of the worst professors I have ever had, avoid at any cost.

One positive is that he does not assign much homework. His lectures are dry and he does not seem very friendly. He never responded to emails and was extremely hard to reach outside of class. You can tell that he is a very smart guy and has a deep understanding of mathematics, but that does not translate into his lectures. Good luck if you have him.

Definitely a very smart man. However, it's difficult to understand him. I gave up on in-person classes and watched his youtube recordings instead because I kept needing to go back & repeat. His exams are only 4 questions with short answers; barely any partial credit. So if you're smart and prepared but just don't know one thing, get ready for a C.
I never really understood how he graded and never did corrections on paper.

You basically have to teach yourself class. He's very hard to understand and teaches in a way that is confusing and makes no sense. He will rarely teach the material on the exam and doesn't even test you on the stuff in the study guide. I honestly don't know how he's still teaching here.

Professor Derdzinski is a genius person. He cares about students in office hours. His lectures are dry and long, but if you review textbooks before exams, it will be an easy A. Tests are heavy but very straightforward. There is not many homework per week.

Smart man, poor professor. Lectures were recordings on Youtube with no editing to remove mistakes and long, stammering pauses. Jumped around between topics with no clear connections given between them and explanations were poor at best. I only passed because the book is decent and TheMathCoach and Faculty of Kahn on Youtube helped immensely.

Honestly a little misunderstood on here so far I think. He really is a great guy and absolutely brilliant. Read the section in the 'textbook' before class and it helps your understanding a lot. He goes a little too fast sometimes but he really knows what he's talking about. Unbelievably tough grader.
Nice handsome fellow trying to make people smarter day by day. Easy A.

Good professor in my opinion. 3 homework problems per week and every lecture starts pretty much on time without any sort of small talk. He is very specific on the board when he is talking and makes things clear through his writing (although it is very mathematical writing). He doesn't remind you to do your homework (but it's due every Monday).

Andrzej is amazing at explaining the content of this course in a thorough and easy to understand way. He goes a bit fast but not so fast that it's impossible to keep up with. Midterms are fairly easy and the course load is dealable with. Make sure you read the textbook alongside or even before the lecture.

The worst professor I have ever had. Yeah, I mean it. He is obviously very smart, But he makes every single thing complicated and just talks to student in his way. I basically learn stuff by myself for whole semester. In addition, he graded heavily on exams while every exam has only 4-6 questions. If you miss one, you are screwed.

Great mathematician. Loves imparting his knowledge to eager students. Loves proofs. Office hours are quite good if you walk in with specific questions and are willing to put in the effort to understand what he says. Note that he doesn't like dumbing down ideas. He's a purist so don't take his class unless you love math and like a challenge.

Professor Derdzinski, while a brilliant mathematician, is simply a terrible teacher. He speaks directly into the board while lecturing, never stopping for input from students. If he stays on topic in lecture, it's a miracle - he flies through proofs without explaining any concepts. Midterms were 4 questions each, final was 6. Don't take his class.

The guy very obviously is versed at what he teaches, but is pretty bad when it comes to actually transferring the information. Tests are few, weighty, and there is basically no partial credit (we had a group of ten students approach him on this matter, only to get a short and rude response). If you learn from practical examples, AVOID.

Complains about how the textbook was written, but fails to explain the material clearly himself. Lectures do not prepare you for the quizzes or the exams, so be prepared to read the book and try to solve every problems. Very general explanations about the topics, but will require more knowledge on the exams, even for simple problems.

If you choose to attend his lectures you will more than likely end up staring into space or sitting on your phone more than taking notes. He does not clearly and efficiently go over the topics that are on the tests in class and during recitation he discusses random topics that will never be needed. Basically you will teach yourself the course.

Well-organized prof. tried to cover everything in complex analysis but only tested on major topics so don't get panic if you cant't follow in the lecture.  will post topic(s) before every examquiz and they are fair if you review notes, read textbook(very important) and do the practice problems he suggested. he is fair and wants you to do well!
Excellent professor ... highly recommend.

He makes many mistakes during his lectures so taking notes becomes pointless. Test and quizzes all boil down to remembering some "trick" or be punished with lots of algebra. Sometimes, he will place a restriction on the way you can solve problems - thus forcing you to try and figure out the "trick" or get zero credit. Horrible.

He is the worst instructor I have ever had at OSU and it's not even close. More than half the class dropped when I took the class Autumn 2014. The answers and help he provides to students in office hours is inconsistent with how this mysterious graduate TA graded. Dropped my math minor because of him. DO NOT take this class under any circumstances.

Quite possibly the worst professor I have ever had in my entire educational career. Lectures are abstract and worthless. No solutions are available for any of the practice problems, so you have no idea if you are doing anything right ever. Tests are very short and partial credit is non existent. Avoid if you don't want to take the class twice.

Quizzes and tests were very easy in retrospect. Although, you really have to do the homework problems because his lectures are almost completely abstract and proof-oriented. If you mess up, it's not likely you'll get a lot of partial credit...  You can tell this guy is a genius, it's not a surprise he doesn't want to be in that room.

Second midterm average was a 39 and he didn't curve. He also refused to help the students. With three weeks to go, the entire class went to the math department and requested to switch sections and things were so bad that they let us do that. Do NOT take his class!
Derdzinski is by far, the worst professor I have ever had at OSU. He is of no help and he is the most ridiculous grader I have ever had. Studying is of no avail in this course.

Listen, I read these reviews before I took the class, but I found a few redeeming ones so I chanced it.  90% of people here say he goes into class, talks really fast at the board, and runs away after it's over, and that's the TRUTH!!!  I could go on about how terribly he conducted our course, but I don't have room.

Quizzes and tests were fair, although you have to be careful not to make mistakes. Homework was very light. His teaching was passable, although I skipped a lot. Easy class if you read the book and do the homework.

This guy is your standard foreign teacher. His lectures are difficult to understand.  Shows up late for every class, and exams. His exams are fair.  The first one was hard, but the second was very easy. Final was fair. His exams consist of very few problems, and he gives aweful partial credit.  Without a good ta, this class will be difficult.

Derdzinkski marches rapidly through proofs, and it's very easy to get lost.  I often can't make sense of my notes when I look at them after class because he goes pretty fast and doesn't write every important step down.  In addition, he seems a bit resistant to helping during office hours.  He covers more material than other sections.  Avoid!

Like several before have said, he is late to class and then the first one to leave.  He talks continuously to the board, without giving a second for students to think through each step.  He is extremely unhelpful, in class and in office hours; he just re-reads the question back to you.  I would not have him as a professor again.

Andrzej is a brilliant (slightly scatter-brained) man.  If you ask him questions in his office, he is quite nice and helpful.  His lectures can be hard to follow in real time, but if you review your notes, you will find that you can learn a lot from him.  His tests and grades are fair. With a little bit of effort, you will be lucky to have had him.

Horrible teacher yet extremely intelligent. Most lectures were way to advanced for students in the class. I went to every lecture (don't know why), because I am making myself teach the material. Without a good TA, I would be more lost than I already am. If anyway possible-AVOID
Horrible!!! This guy just eats math books, comes to class, and spits it all out really fast. Doesnt realize other people are actually in the room. Totally awful lecture.
makes things harder than they r, way to fast, jumps around way to much
This man speaks to the board, rushes through examples, never prepares, somehow manages to cover neither theory nor applications adequately, is horribly unsightly and should be avoided at all costs.

Teaches more theory than most engineers could handle, which is the source of most complaints here. Linear algebra background helps for dif eq. (period) Extremely unorganized. He chose a worthless textbook. Easy class, easy exams if you read carefully.
Not a very good teacher.  I suggest making bets on which tee shirt he wears each day.  That was my only   enjoyable part of the class
Horrible Teacher.  Comes in late, talks to the board, doesn't seem to care if you succeed or fail.  Seems to try as hard as he can to trick you on tests.  Definitley run the other way from him.

Always late, late for final. Always wore the same clothes. Found ducks in lake were more interesting. So unclear. Told us something WAS NOT going to be on final, then reviewed it and said we would need it to solve a problem..yup. Final was not as expected. Namely: crazy!

He is not a good professor but he should work for Nasa or something.  You cannot approach him to ask questions because he is late to class and is the first one out of the classroom.  If you take his class I would recommend attending every recitation, to understand what is going on.
No Comments

This guy is somewhat unorganized, but overall, I believe he is a good teacher.  He knows his subject matter, but doesn't explain it the best ways to typical students.  He speaks to the class like they're getting their PH.d.  He tells you what is going to be on tests and is a lenient grader.
This guy is awful.  He takes what should be an easy class and makes it way too unclear and confusing.  Stay away from him.
Anyone who complains about this guy is just plain lazy.  He tells you what is on the tests, gives good examples and his final grades are way nice.
This professor was horrible, I learned nothing from him. I would advise people not to take his class.

A math genius, but imagine a physics student getting lectured by einstien (in german). tough to understand, but practise tests were helpful. I had to retake, as did several friends. It is very easy to cheat if you sit in the back of class (still got a D).

Terrible teacher.  Too smart to teach.  The only way he was helpful is because so many people complained that he now gives practice tests.  He got behind and decided not to teach things that we needed to know for later.  Don't take him.

Great professor. You can tell he is very knowledgeable and loves teaching. Class is pretty difficult and it can go from 0 to 100 real quick if you don't pay attention, but he's not afraid to stop lecture to answer questions. Exams & quizzes were all online, and mimic the notes. Although he posts online notes, going in person is 10x better.

Dr. Johnson is probably your best bet as a professor for upper level math courses! His lectures were super useful and exams and quizzes were take home open note. Linear Algebra is a tough course but if professor Johnson made it a lot better for us.

Professor Johnson is an awesome teacher. Our section he made live Zoom classes which he posted right after class in case you could not make it. He responds to emails and offers assistance after class or during office hours. Genuinely the best math professor I've had in a very long time.

Great caring and passionate professor, easy to understand. Grades consisted of textbook surveys (reading chapter, saying whats easy/hard), 9 homeworks (took some time), two exams, and a final. Exams and final were timed online open note. The class was very manageable and structured very well.

Prof. Johnson was great! I have had really bad experiences with the Math department at OSU, but he's an absolute godsend. Exams and quizzes are easy by virtue of them being open note, and him leaving hints on the harder questions. My only gripe is the textbook readings are a little confusing, and I thought they weren't really that helpful.

Professor Johnson was truly chill. He gives a lot of assignments but its a good thing so that you can help raise your grade! Exams were super similar to homework and quizzes as well. He did often lose his students but overall the class was manageable and not too daunting!

Prof Johnson is a valid professor. Sometimes he gets carried away with lectures and loses students with some topics. Overall, he made concepts somewhat easy to understand. His exams mirrored his homework, which mirrored the notes, which is nice. Go to office hours and you will see how great of a person/prof he is. One-on-one is were he is the best.

I was in his online, synchronous Linear Algebra class and Professor Johnson is a very considerate professor who explains all concepts very well in class and was always willing to make extra recordings and host office hours to explain all concepts. He assigns weekly problem sets that do a very good job of preparing you for exams!

Top Hat was used, and almost each class he took the attendance. Also, there were many pop questions during the class. Not only answering the questions matters, but also you should get the right answer to get full credits. I think he is a tough grader, even the means of exams are always low, he didn't give a curve.

Prof. Johnson is an absolute gem of a human but I have never had more issues with a class in my life. This was his first go at 2153 and his tests had so many errors and typos that it was impossible to do well on the tests. I got 100% on every quiz in the class and failed every single midterm. Now I have to retake the course.

I'm not one to complain about professors very much, but he was pretty bad. Everyone I talked to in my section had complaints about him and he was hardly accessible because he cancelled most of his office hours. He explains things in a manner that only make you more confused and just assumes you know everything instead of clarifying concepts

Prof. Johnson is an amazing lecturer. His passion for teaching and mathematics history is inspirational. Now, the class is itself very though, a lot of proofs and concepts that I was unfamiliar with (engineering background), but he did his best to make them understandable. The difficulty level is 4 because of him, otherwise it would be infinity.

Dr. Johnson seemed like a wonderful person. He was always accessible after class and really seemed to care about his students. However, I really didn't like his lecture style. I always came out of lecture confused and not really understanding what was going on. To each their own and maybe you will connect with his teaching style.

Not only does Professor John Johnson Jr. easily have the best name in the math department, but hes also the best lecturer that Ive had so far. His curriculum is pretty average compared to other profs, but his lecture was incredible: organized as can be and easy to follow. His passion for mathematics, its history, and his students are unmatched.
I guess it is because that the class is at 8 am and it is calculus 2. But I can barely remember anything that he said during class. Online classes are definitely better.

It's hard to judge Johnson by Math 1151 (Calc I) bc this course is 100% department run. A lot of students would get mad at him for midterms, homework, or really anything, but literally everything is by department. He did give attendance points. He rarely covered everything in lecture, but the math department posts online lessons which I used a ton

Tests were challenging. Lectures were confusing to follow a lot of the time. Very stressful course. Practice midterms and recitation packets helped a lot for studying (all I used). Online textbook was glitchy so I never really used. If you have another choice, don't take 1151. Take algebra or pre-calculus.

I really liked having Dr. Johnson for calc 1. His lectures were very helpful, but sometimes he wasnt able to teach the whole lesson, so he always posted the notes online. He cares about his students and definitely REALLY wants them to succeed. Tests are hard, so make sure you fully understand the material, and go to office hours if youre stuck.

I like Professor Johnson, he was a good teacher for ENGR Calc A, which is essentially Calc 2 and some of 3. Then again, I had learned up through the second midterm in high school (Calc BC), so I received an A without too much difficulty.
good
Class was very boring and hard to follow. Exams did not match the material covered in class and the TopHat questions were a waste of time because they did not help.
John Johnson made an amazing comeback after being star quarterback for the Oregon State Beavers. He went undrafted, so his football career never took off like Johnny Manziel's.

He seemed like a really great guy. I took him for the active learning class. The setup of the class seemed promising but wasn't too helpful and was confusing. Had  a great recitation TA but the final exam was a huge twist. Nothing could have prepared me for that. I passed because I was retaking the course. #secondtimesthecharm

I was in the Active Calculus class and if you ignore how bad the math department tries to challenge everyone, he is a really good person to talk to if you need help. If you talk to him as much as you can, he is more than willing to work with you if you need a grade boost.

Johnson is helpful in office hours. Kind of an awkward person to talk to but he's really nice. Lectures can be confusing and he doesn't always cover all the material. Teaches examples but not so much concepts. I was in his first section of "active learning calculus" and it was just kind of all over the place. Mandatory group homework which sucked.

The only reason I passed is because I took Calc in high school and had a great teacher.  His lectures often confused me on topics that were easy, he made everything more complicated than it needed to be.  My friend and I started going to the lecture after his and found it much more helpful. He won't give back any test points and grades way too hard

Dr. Johnson tries his best to make lectures interesting. The lectures are often confusing and he does have a tendency to make concepts more intricate than they really are, but if you go to office hours he will describe the concepts in much easier terms. He is always willing to help. He is also very nerdy, which I loved.

I think I could have never gone to a lecture and been fine in this class. I suppose they were mildly helpful, but what he discussed was never really pertinent to the exams and I probably taught myself more out of the book and with other online help. Seemingly nice guy though.  (And as an avid Star Wars fan, quit the references dude.)

I had Dr. Johnson for "Active Calculus" (Math 1151), and for his teaching style to be very confusing.  He uses a lot of Star Wars references and silly analogies that didn't make sense to me.  I don't think his lectures prepared me for the quizzes, midterms, or final at all.  The MSLC was my go to for the semester, I watched all the online lessons.

I took an "Active Calculus" class with Dr. Johnson and overall  he was alright. His lectures did not cover really what were on the department wide midterms. He made lectures interesting with Star Wars references and interactive lessons. But most times I learned the most from online lessons offered through the MSLC. He was helpful and nice though.

John Johnson is an OK professor. His lectures are really confusing, so unless you like the philosophy of math theory, take someone else. I ended up going to another professor's lectures, and after that, I understood the material better. He's nice, but if you want a good understanding  the material, take someone else. He takes a partipation grade
